Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2013 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Hayden Schaeffer is "Sparse Methods for Imaging and Partial Differential Equations." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of California-Irvine, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Hongkai Zhao.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was made as part of the FY 2013 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship was "Sparse Methods for Imaging and Partial Differential Equations." The sponsoring scientists are Dr. Hongkai Zhao (University of California, Irvine) and Dr. Thomas Y. Hou (California Institute of Technology).

 

Numerical methods for approximating nonlinear and/or multiscale phenomena are essential tools for scientific computing. These structures appear throughout science and industry in, for example, materials science, fluid dynamics, imaging, etc. One major computational challenge involves the need to resolve multiple structures/scales, which often leads to numerical issues due to complexity. Using sparse optimization, the goal of this project was to approximate solutions of nonlinear partial differential equations and variational problems using less information while preserving the accuracy. The main mathematical technique is to incorporate L1 penalties into the variational formulation for various problems. In particular, the problems studied included: resolving highly oscillatory dynamics using sparse basis approximations, sparse decompositions for conservations laws, and L1 relaxation techniques for the obstacle problem. This project also included the mentoring of undergraduate and graduate students.
